data.title: Clicking on Search results does not scroll to line
data.body:
Hi all,
This used to work in previous versions, but searching in Atom and ultimately selecting the line within a file used to open the file and scroll you to that specific point in the file. It currently is shooting me to the end of the editor each time.

data.title: Remove stacktrace-parser
data.body: I couldn't find any part of the code that used this, so here goes!

data.title: Improve Windows build instructions
data.body:
Based on my experience with getting Atom to build on Windows, I decided to try to refresh the Windows docs.

Changes:
- Node.js download link changed from http://nodejs.org/download/ to http://nodejs.org/en/download/.  The new link is an actual webpage, not just a list of files :P
- Restructured the requirements section
- Added explicit note about `GYP_MSVS_VERSION` (this was the cause of all my troubles :cry:)
- Included VS 2015 in the troubleshooting section
- Other minor grammatical changes

/cc @paulcbetts @raelyard @atom/feedback for review

data.title: Atom always opens keymap.cson on startup
data.body:
Atom 1.0.19 running on Windows 7

Steps to reproduce:
- Make sure all tabs are closed
- Terminate Atom (File/Exit)
- Start Atom

I would expect that no tab is open, but the tab keymap.cson is always opened.

data.title: Input fields in settings getting reverted whilst typing at random
data.body:
So I have this issue, whenever I type anything into a field in the settings page it reverts it back to what was previously input at random. Not sure whats going on here but I have a video showing the behaviour:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pIJo3DCjv6w

It only seems to affect settings that are displayed on this panel. Settings for plugins etc works fine in input boxes so I am unsure if its just the saving mechanism you guys have for the main settings page causing issues. 

To give more info: 

I am using Windows 10
I am using Atom version 1.0.19

data.title: Add the help-wanted and beginner issues to the contributing guide
data.body: The new title is sentence case. Wasnt sure on a good, clear title for it other than this one.

data.title: tab closing order
data.body:
With three tabs open and the middle one active, closing the tab makes the tab on the left active, whereas in Chrome or Safari, closing the the current tab makes the tab to its right active.

Maybe it's an intentional decision and there's no issue, but it isn't expected behavior to me.

Atom 1.0.19
OS X Yosemite 10.10.5

data.title: no debian i386 version?
data.body: i noticed the amd64 version but didn't see a i386 version...any in the works?

data.title: ECMAScript 2015 "constant" chaining
data.body:
Hey, when using the`const` ECMAScript 2015 feature in a chain on a JavaScript document, the chained variable names aren't classified as "constant"s...

Take this code piece:

``` javascript
const path = require('path'),
      fs = require('fs');
```

(Notice how GitHub does it too...  Lol)

Here is what it looks like in the editor:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6251703/10494185/1eb045ca-7272-11e5-97bf-67ff87a6a8d3.png)

Despite this being valid way to define constants in JavaScript, Atom doesn't signify that as such...

When peaking in the HTML structure you see that the first keyword is classified as a constant:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6251703/10494213/50e5ab34-7272-11e5-9a42-ba814c47c76e.png)

But the second keyword in the chain is not, and is simply loose, not classed as anything:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6251703/10494255/7fa5ea9c-7272-11e5-85d3-a320b43a17d9.png)

Note that this also happens if you use more than two in the chains...  Only the first keyword is classified as a `"constant"`.

data.title: Long tab lengths fail, and default back to 4
data.body:
Manually setting the tab length beyond 8, say to `16` or `40`, causes the tab length to become 4. This is true both when set from the user's config file and when specified in the settings of a package. Long tabs are useful for spreadsheet editing, given that neither Excel nor Numbers support multiple cursors or regex-find-replace.

This is indirectly related related to #8261. I can't fathom why Atom moralizes on tab length. Sure, 4-length soft tabs are superior, but there are legitimate reasons for using other permutations.

data.title: Support \A regex anchor for matching beginning of string
data.body: This is often useful in Find & Replace, and worked in ST. But it's also useful in grammar packages where special behavior is desired for the 1st line

data.title: Automatically filter by popularity when searching packages

Suggestion: when searching for packages through Atom, make it default to list the options by popularity.
Right now it displays a lot of clutter before the actual package you're probably looking for.

data.title: Avoid stack overflow when scrolling with non-integer values
data.body: We were mistakenly using the rounded scroll top to guard against such cases. This fixes it by using `@realScrollTop` instead.

data.title: Can not save new document if keymap.cson is open
data.body:
Atom for Windows 1.0.19

Please have a look at the first screenshot attached: I have several tabs open in Atom, among them one 'untitled' with new text, and one keymap.cson, which was opened because I had done a "File/OpenYourKeyjmap" (but the keymap was not modified). The focus is inside the "untitled" tab.

Now I click on File/SaveAs, and I get the error dialogue which you can see in the second screenshot.

As you can see, writing is refused on the grounds that Atom can not save to this directory (even though I have full permissions), and if you look at the filename proposed by Atom, it says "keymap". From this I conclude that Atom wants to save keymap.cson, instead of the untitled file.

However, even after closing the tab containing the keymap, "SaveAs" gives a similar error message (same meaning, though different wording) and insists in using "keymap" as a filename for my untitled document, but now a workaround is possible: I click on OK and change the file name from "keymap" to whatever I want, and now it is possible to save the file.

![capture_20151014_105610](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6795665/10479148/bacf2b02-7262-11e5-9a1e-33958dc0ac96.jpg)
![capture_20151014_105628](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6795665/10479152/bf01c522-7262-11e5-921c-3b4ab0f0d639.jpg)

data.title: API Proposal: Decoration layers
data.body:
Note: This document is currently aspirational, and describes the hypothetical design of an API that is yet to be implemented.

/cc @as-cii @maxbrunsfeld
## Overview

Decoration layers provide an alternative API to marker-based decorations for situations in which creating markers is too expensive. Two examples are spell check and find and replace. With decoration layers, instead of creating a marker for every single decoration in the buffer, package authors can perform work incrementally to describe only the decorations for the currently-visible portion of the buffer.
### Creating a decoration layer

Decoration layers are created by calling the `addDecorationLayer` method with a single function.

``` js
let layer = textEditor.addDecorationLayer(function (visibleBufferRange) {
  return [ /* ... decoration descriptors ... */ ]
})
```
### Returning decorations

When necessary, the editor will call this function with a `Range` object representing the currently visible portion of the screen, in buffer coordinates. A full range is used rather than row numbers because due to soft wrapping, only a portion of a line in the buffer might be visible. Buffer coordinates are used rather than screen coordinates because they map more directly to most kinds of analyses required for decorations, such as scanning for search matches or highlighting misspellings.

To ensure a smooth visual experience, the decoration layer function is synchronous. We may want to discuss allowing decoration layers to return promises, but this would lead to decorations flickering into view and is unacceptable for our initial use cases.

The return value of a decoration layer's function should be an array of decoration descriptor objects. Each descriptor can contain any of the parameters passed to `decorateMarker` to create marker-based decorations, such as `type`, `class`, etc. In addition, each descriptor object must contain a `bufferRange` key, describing the range to which the decoration applies. Returned ranges should all overlap with the `visibleBufferRange` passed to the function.
### Decoration layer methods

The `DecorationLayer` object returned by the call to `addDecorationLayer` has two methods, `update` and `destroy`.

Decoration layer functions will be called automatically when the contents of their editor changes. When decorations change for other reasons, you'll need to manually inform the editor that your layer needs to be re-rendered by calling `update`. This method is asynchronous, meaning a call to update only schedules a view update for the next animation frame. We can potentially return a promise that resolves when the update is completed if it's needed.

To remove the decoration layer, call `destroy` on it.
## Implementation
### Interpolation

Decoration layers need to be fast enough not to impose undue overhead when the visible range changes on the editor. However, performing a full-screen search on every keystroke is untenable. The solution to this problem is interpolation.

When the buffer changes, should debounce calls into user-defined decoration functions so as to only perform them at the end of a sequence of changes. In the meantime, we'll want to keep decorations in the correct logical location during edits by maintaining a local marker index. When changes occur to the buffer, we'll apply them to the layer's marker index synchronously, but we won't re-query the user-defined function for each change.

I'd like to use this as a chance to test drive our new [1-d marker index](https://github.com/atom/marker-index) library. Changes will need to be converted to absolute coordinates in order to use it, but it's the cleanest and fastest implementation and I'd like to migrate to using it in `TextBuffer` if it works out in this use case. We shouldn't store decorations as markers on the `TextBuffer`, because there's a ton of overhead associated with creating mutable markers that's unnecessary in this case. Interacting at a low level directly with an index will have much lower overhead.

To avoid the need to row-and-column-based points to absolute character offsets repeatedly, we may want to change the buffer APIs to include offset information. We'll need to calculate this information in the buffer anyway to accomodate use of the new marker index.

Another tool that might be useful to aggregate changes is a [patch data structure](https://github.com/nathansobo/atom-patch). This allows a sequence of potentially-overlapping splice operations to be recorded into the patch, and then be played back in a coalesced form asynchronously. Including the offset information and just writing synchronously into the marker index is probably easier, but it's worth keeping in mind that an efficient change-tracking data structure exists.
### Updates to the view/model relationship

Currently, we return visible decorations from the model to the view in an object that's indexed by marker id. I think we should add a new, private method to the model that's intended to be consumed by the view. It should return an array of decoration descriptors, each containing a range, so that the view layer no longer needs to interact with markers. This will make it possible to unify our handling of marker- and layer-based decorations in the view in a single code path. The model will be in charge of querying the marker store and decoration layers and combining everything into a single array of data to be consumed.

data.title: Ubuntu keymap when non-EN keyboard layout active is wrong
data.body:
When running Atom under Ubuntu (14.04 LTS, I believe) with vim-mode and ex-mode installed and using a JP keyboard layout (see:https://www-01.ibm.com/software/globalization/topics/keyboards/images/fig3_new.GIF) the keys are not mapped correctly. Specifically, in the circumstance that was causing me issue, when I press the : key to bring up ex-mode (which is where ' is for QWERTY layout) nothing happened. When I opened the key binding resolver, I saw that it was being mapped to ;, and I had to press the normal SHIFT+; key combo in order to get Atom to recognize the : key and open ex-mode. Oddly, typing in the code window (and even the ex-mode area) showed the correct keys.

Using Atom on a Macbook with the same JP layout does not exhibit this issue. I have not tested on Windows.

data.title: Update Node versions in the docs
data.body: Instead of specifying both node.js and io.js, just say "node.js 0.10.x or above" now that node.js and io.js have merged.

data.title: Files keeps marked as modified
data.body:
I have the following problem wit the Git integration:
1) I open a folder with a .git folder in it, right click->open with atom
2) I modified just one line
3) Atom thinks the whole file is modified. So the file is orange, and the status bar says for example:
![knipsel](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2659866/10468247/4fa6286c-71fe-11e5-8d00-6e2feb626398.PNG)
But at the begin of the lines, just after the line numbers, there is no sign of any modified lines.

I also happens sometimes that the whole file list is marked as modified (al files are orange).
When I run `git status` it says the repository is clean, and there are no new commits, new files of modified files.
### System information

OS: Windows 7
Atom version: 1.0.19

data.title: :memo: Better workspace scan and replace docs
Fix setting default values in config
data.body: Fixes https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/9032

data.title: unfoldAll is slow
data.body:
If a function does many consecutive folds or unfolds, it's very slow. On an 8000-line file with many folds, `editor.unfoldAll()` takes more than 12 secs. Profiling shows that calls to `Fold.updateDisplayBuffer` are the problem. That's called after each fold/unfold. If I first fold the whole buffer and then run `unfoldAll`, it runs in under 1 sec because screen updates are not isn't run if a folds is nested. It looks like that approach might work for folding, too, but I haven't tried it.

It would be nice if there was a way to disable display updates for longer fold/unfold operations.

This is with Atom 1.0.19 under Windows 10.
